body:
Unicode troubles again. There's a lot of work on unicode gone into what will become 0.11, so if you're OK running trunk from git, hopefully it will work there. If not, we'll definitely fix it before releasing 0.11. (Even if you don't want to run it day to day, can we ask you to test? Most of the core developers are on Linux or Mac. Thanks.)

As for fixing the error in 0.10.2: does it show a traceback of where the error occurs? If so, can you post a copy of that traceback?

Just got this same issue, running 0.11 git trunk on Mac.

  File "/Users/rspeer/src/ipython/IPython/core/interactiveshell.py", line 1600, in refill_readline_hist
    self.readline.add_history(line.encode(stdin_encoding))
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode characters in position 19-20: ordinal not in range(128)

An easy fix is to change that to: line.encode(stdin_encoding, 'replace')

You may want to do that anywhere in iPython that you're encoding unknown text into an unknown encoding. Throwing an error is rarely going to be the right answer.

You're right, we should. Although what you're seeing is probably an indication of some deeper problem. `stdin_encoding` should be coming from `sys.stdin.encoding` if it can find it. The fact that it's "ascii" indicates that it probably can't, and is falling back on the default encoding. Is your setup unusual in any way? What do you get for `sys.stdin.encoding`?

From git ipython 0.11

  File "C:\Temp\ipython-ipython-55f24ba\IPython\frontend\terminal\ipapp.py", line 395, in create_default_config

  File "C:\Temp\ipython-ipython-55f24ba\IPython\core\application.py", line 241, in create_default_config
    c.Global.ipython_dir = get_ipython_dir()
  File "C:\Temp\ipython-ipython-55f24ba\IPython\utils\path.py", line 312, in get_ipython_dir
    return ipdir.decode(sys.getfilesystemencoding())
  File "C:\Python27\lib\encodings\mbcs.py", line 21, in decode
    return mbcs_decode(input, errors, True)
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\u0142' in position 14: ordinal not in range(128)
I had similar problem with django but I found solution in that ticket http://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/15778

Oh, wait, I see what it's doing. It's trying to decode a string that's already unicode. And Python 2 handles that situation by...attempting to convert the unicode back to an 8-bit string using the default encoding, namely ascii. Resulting in an _encoding_ error from a _decoding_ function...

Anyway, all we should need to do is to check if it's already unicode before we attempt to return it. I'll whip up a pull request.
Can you try with my ipdir-unicode branch? Thanks. https://github.com/takluyver/ipython/tree/ipdir-unicode

I don't think the problem is that it's deciding that the fs is ascii (it's not, it's correctly identified as 'mbcs'), it's that we are calling 'decode' on a unicode object (ipdir), which is legal for some reason, but a terrible idea.  When you call `u.decode(enc)`, you end up calling `u.encode(sys.defautencoding()).decode(enc)`, and it's that intermediate encode step that's failing.

I think you are right that 'replace' is the right answer for stdin/out handling of unknown data (we do that elsewhere, but clearly not enough).  However, I don't think it's true that it is the right answer for files.  If we can't interpret a symbol correctly, that probably should be an error.  If we silently substitute a character, the user could be told that a file they _did not ask for_ doesn't exist, or worse, perform actions on files they do not intend.

Looking at the django ticket, it would appear that locale.getdefaultlocale()[-1] is sometimes preferred.  On Windows, defaultlocale returns 'cp1252' and sys.filesystemencoding is 'mbcs'.  I don't know what's better here, but it might be significant to note that neither will work for Michał.  There is no cp1252 representation for 'ł', and mbcs coerces it to 'l' (lower L).  Both of which will give the wrong answer.

Michał, can you report the output of `locale.getdefaultlocale()` on your system?

Further, I cannot seem to find any way to get Michał's real unicode name from the system in Python _at all_. Everything reports 'Michal'.  Anybody have ideas on this?

'mbcs' seems to be just a reference to your system code page, so it may not do the same thing on your computer as on Michał's.

However, I think the way that we should do this is just to use Unicode strings, as it seems to be doing without our help. According to PEP 277, Python since 2.3 will try to use Windows' native Unicode APIs for file access where you give it Unicode strings. It's already doing what it should, we're just messing it up by trying to decode again. I think the tiny change in my ipdir-unicode branch should solve it.
Investigation suggests that you need to set your Windows code page to 1250 or 1257 to replicate the environment. I don't know which Michał has, but both contain the ł character.

> My windows user name is "Michał" and ipython apparently can't work with non-ascii character but how fix it?

Can you please send the full traceback?  We'll need to know where the
problem is happening before we can fix it...

Thanks

@fperez You don't get follow up comments as email notifications until you've participated in the conversation.  It's probably a good idea to always send your first reply from the Issues page, in case there's been discussion already, as there has been here.

@takluyver I get https://github.com/takluyver/ipython/tree/ipdir-unicode and it work! Thanks ipython created some files in C:\Users\Michał.ipython so it seems that ipython gets right way to my user folder @minrk If you still need it: 
>>> locale.getdefaultlocale()
('pl_PL', 'cp1250')

OK, great, I'll make a pull request. Thanks, Michał.

@fperez: Do we want to make a fix for the 0.10 series as well? I know we're not planning any more releases for that, but if it won't even start... I guess it depends how common non-ascii usernames are.

I'm seeing a similar problem in OSX. I tried to install from https://github.com/takluyver/ipython/tree/ipdir-unicode, but I'm not sure that it worked (sorry, new to OSX and git for that matter). I'm still getting a UnicodeEncodeError.

@cdeboever3: It doesn't seem that it's installed correctly, it's calling methods that aren't in git head. I don't know about installing on macs, I'm afraid.

@cdeboever3 You have more than one IPython installed. You installed to `/System/Library/...`, but you still have IPython in `/Library/Python/...` which comes first.  So your most recently installed IPython is not being used.

That said, @takluyver's pull request _does not_ fix the issue you are seeing, which is also mentioned in the discussion above.  I did just now push a fix for your bug to master (as suggested by @rspeer).
Thanks for the info. I can't figure out how to install ipython to the directory where it needs to be, but hopefully I can figure it out and try the bug fix.

I see that the ticket is closed, however I simply wanted to offer a quick & dirty solution pending a new release of ipython (or for those who can't or don't want to update to a newer version).

I was getting exact same error on OS10.6, using ipython 0.11 dev (full trackeback at the bottom). I deleted both ~/.ipython/history and ~/.ipython/history.json and now ipython starts up just fine. I assume that the issue came about from having previously issued ipython commands containing unicode characters ? I sometimes use the french-canadian keyboard so this might have tripped up ipython when trying to parse the history file. Anyway... HTH !

Thanks otherwise for a great tool !

Ninja edit: I can confirm that this is indeed the issue. Typing "é" at the ipython prompt yields the following error:
In [3]: é
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\xe9' in position 0: ordinal not in range(128)
after which iPython fails to reload (with exact same error message as before). Deleting history.json fixes this.

@gdesjardins: The dev version you're using is out of date. If you want to grab the latest code from Github, it shouldn't have a problem with unicode input. We're planning to turn this into a release in the next couple of weeks or so.
